values.title: Find a better place to host teleop code

content.raw: It is useful for Linux but it is not tested on Windows or Mac. We should review if it makes sense to keep it in this repository.
content.html: It is useful for Linux but it is not tested on Windows or Mac. We should review if it makes sense to keep it in this repository.

values.title: Testing on Windows7 32bits version (Visual Studio + MATLAB)

content.raw:
Our main development platform has been Windows 7 64bits.

It will help to see if things are working on a native 32bits version of Windows.
content.html:
Our main development platform has been Windows 7 64bits.

It will help to see if things are working on a native 32bits version of Windows.

content.raw:
It would be nice to have 64 dependencies available:

What is needed:

 * protobuf in win64: need to be compiled in visual studio
 * zeromq in win64: provided by zeromq, just need to be zipped

cppzmq is just a header file and just fine.

Remember to update the make_sdk to use a parameter for creating the different arch sdk version.
content.html:
It would be nice to have 64 dependencies available:

What is needed:

  • protobuf in win64: need to be compiled in visual studio
  • zeromq in win64: provided by zeromq, just need to be zipped

cppzmq is just a header file and just fine.

Remember to update the make_sdk to use a parameter for creating the different arch sdk version.

values.title: Place all the Windows stuff into a subdirectory

content.raw: Not urgent, but should think on moving all the windows stuff into a common directory called tools/win or win or whatever. This includes .bat files and property sheet.
content.html: Not urgent, but should think on moving all the windows stuff into a common directory called tools/win or win or whatever. This includes .bat files and property sheet.

values.title: Catch up implementation with new API

content.raw: [PR#37](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/pull-request/37/) updated the API to reflect DARPA's specifications, but the features have not been implemented (such as timestamp). We should consider implementing these features.
content.html: PR#37 updated the API to reflect DARPA's specifications, but the features have not been implemented (such as timestamp). We should consider implementing these features.

content.raw: The code looks correct on the client side, but the `joint_limit` array is all zeros.  Probably something needs to be updated on the server side.
content.html: The code looks correct on the client side, but the joint_limit array is all zeros. Probably something needs to be updated on the server side.

content.raw: It complains when > 0 args are provided.  We should allow args to be optionally passed into the MATLAB function (but then ignore them when calling into the mex function).
content.html: It complains when > 0 args are provided. We should allow args to be optionally passed into the MATLAB function (but then ignore them when calling into the mex function).

content.raw:
There's something wrong with our use of `mexErrMsgIdAndTxt()` that causes this error to be printed in MATLAB:

    Error using hxgz

    The error message identifier is invalid.

It works fine in Octave.  Maybe the first argument should be a registered identifier of some sort.
content.html:
There's something wrong with our use of mexErrMsgIdAndTxt() that causes this error to be printed in MATLAB:

Error using hxgz

The error message identifier is invalid.

It works fine in Octave. Maybe the first argument should be a registered identifier of some sort.

values.title: hx_update should accept row or column vectors

content.raw: Probably easiest to transpose inputs as needed in the [MATLAB wrapper](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/src/0116f5c24f70548d4a50459f55257e40b531caff/matlab/hx_update.m?at=default#cl-66).
content.html: Probably easiest to transpose inputs as needed in the MATLAB wrapper.

content.raw: Something about our mex code is causing MATLAB to crash on exit, and at least one user reported a crash during a run.
content.html: Something about our mex code is causing MATLAB to crash on exit, and at least one user reported a crash during a run.

content.raw: Users have requested this ability.  Also, several MATLAB issues are not reproducible in Octave, so having MATLAB support on Linux will simplify testing.
content.html: Users have requested this ability. Also, several MATLAB issues are not reproducible in Octave, so having MATLAB support on Linux will simplify testing.

content.raw:
It would be nice, but not necessary, to support different Matlab versions: 2013b and 2014a in particular.

Many teams were under the misconception that they would have to run Matlab on Linux, and it felt awkward to explain that we don't support Matlab on Linux, so we could also consider compiling a .mex for Matlab on Ubuntu Trusty. (edit: nevermind--this is encapsulated by issue #11 and will be fixed in this [pr](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/pull-request/52/add-support-for-building-matlab-mex-on/diff))

The blocker, I realize, is a licensing issue.

Alternatively we could just document the mex compilation process and tell teams they could compile .mex files for their own platforms if they so desire.
content.html:
It would be nice, but not necessary, to support different Matlab versions: 2013b and 2014a in particular.

Many teams were under the misconception that they would have to run Matlab on Linux, and it felt awkward to explain that we don't support Matlab on Linux, so we could also consider compiling a .mex for Matlab on Ubuntu Trusty. (edit: nevermind--this is encapsulated by issue #11 and will be fixed in this pr)

The blocker, I realize, is a licensing issue.

Alternatively we could just document the mex compilation process and tell teams they could compile .mex files for their own platforms if they so desire.

content.raw:
on my desktop without matlab installed, if I run `mex` I get

~~~
$ mex
This is pdfTeX, Version 3.1415926-2.5-1.40.14 (TeX Live 2013/Debian)
 restricted \write18 enabled.
**
~~~

so I am guessing it confused the cmake search and determines `MATLAB_FOUND` is true. So if I try to build `haptix-comm`, I get this error:

~~~
/usr/bin/mex: unrecognized option '-outdir'
This is pdfTeX, Version 3.1415926-2.5-1.40.14 (TeX Live 2013/Debian)
 restricted \write18 enabled.
entering extended mode
! I can't find file `/home/hsu/projects/haptix/haptix_comm/build_release/matlab
/matlab'.
<*> ...ix/haptix_comm/build_release/matlab/matlab 
                                                  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/...

(Press Enter to retry, or Control-D to exit)
Please type another input file name: 
~~~

values.title: Create mex wrappers for sim API

content.raw: Wrap up the new sim API in mex functions.
content.html: Wrap up the new sim API in mex functions.

content.raw: Some users will want to create moving targets that can be reached for.  We should add an example of doing this, e.g., to `hxs_example.m`.  Ideally, it would exercise the `hxsDETECTIONONLY` mode and demonstrate contact detection with the limb.
content.html: Some users will want to create moving targets that can be reached for. We should add an example of doing this, e.g., to hxs_example.m. Ideally, it would exercise the hxsDETECTIONONLY mode and demonstrate contact detection with the limb.

values.title: Quaternion example code in matlab is wrong

content.raw:
Our example for manipulating quaternions in matlab (see [matlab/hxs_example.m line 27](#!/osrf/haptix-comm/src/aeda9adbfcf802e68e9afc784126eea59c66ecf5/matlab/hxs_example.m?at=default#cl-27)) looks like the following:

~~~
new_tx.orient(1) += pi/4;
~~~

When I see `pi/4` I think, "Oh this is some kind of angle in radians," but this is actually a quaternion that needs to stay normalized, and this is not a recommended operation for modifying components of a quaternion.

Ideally one would use helper functions for working with quaternions. Matlab provides some through the [Aerospace toolbox](http://www.mathworks.com/help/aerotbx/axes-transformations.html), while Octave has an [external package named quaternion](http://octave.sourceforge.net/quaternion/overview.html) with a different API than Matlab.
content.html:
Our example for manipulating quaternions in matlab (see matlab/hxs_example.m line 27) looks like the following:

new_tx.orient(1) += pi/4;

When I see pi/4 I think, "Oh this is some kind of angle in radians," but this is actually a quaternion that needs to stay normalized, and this is not a recommended operation for modifying components of a quaternion.

Ideally one would use helper functions for working with quaternions. Matlab provides some through the Aerospace toolbox, while Octave has an external package named quaternion with a different API than Matlab.

content.raw: Our code does not require boost anymore. We should remove this requirement from cmake and remove boost from the deps/ directory in the client SDK.
content.html: Our code does not require boost anymore. We should remove this requirement from cmake and remove boost from the deps/ directory in the client SDK.

values.title: hxgz.c does not compile with VS2013 base install

content.raw:
Trying to compile hxgz.c with Visual Studio 2013 base install on Windows 7 throws errors due to a bug in Visual Studio.  This is fixed by applying updates to Visual Studio. I was able to compile fine using VS2013 Update 4.  

This is not a bug with the haptix-comm project, just a note to potentially save someone else some trouble when compiling.
content.html:
Trying to compile hxgz.c with Visual Studio 2013 base install on Windows 7 throws errors due to a bug in Visual Studio. This is fixed by applying updates to Visual Studio. I was able to compile fine using VS2013 Update 4.

This is not a bug with the haptix-comm project, just a note to potentially save someone else some trouble when compiling.

content.raw:
I work with Gazebo HAPTIX(http://gazebosim.org/haptix). Before i used keyboard to control the arm to grasp objects and it worked fine. Then i add the motion tracking system and use function **hxs_set_model_transform** (const char *_name, const hxsTransform *_transform) to control the arm in the simulator, i put this function in a while loop and update it at the frequency of 50Hz. Then i cannot grasp any objects anymore. 
Does the function  **hxs_set_model_transform** do something with the physics engine? Do i do something wrong with using this function?
content.html: I work with Gazebo HAPTIX(http://gazebosim.org/haptix). Before i used keyboard to control the arm to grasp objects and it worked fine. Then i add the motion tracking system and use function hxs_set_model_transform (const char _name, const hxsTransform _transform) to control the arm in the simulator, i put this function in a while loop and update it at the frequency of 50Hz. Then i cannot grasp any objects anymore. Does the function hxs_set_model_transform do something with the physics engine? Do i do something wrong with using this function?

content.raw:
Hi,

I'm a HAPTIX collaborator using the HAPTIX-Gazebo simulation to do some EMG modelling.  I would like to run Gazebo in a VM, (I'm currently using VMWare workstation 12) and develop the code that will be controlling the simulation on my host PC, a Linux PC (Ubuntu 17.04).

I followed the instructions to install and run Gazebo from here: http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=haptix&tut=haptix_install
As such, I used Ubuntu 14.04.  This is running on the Guest.

I can't seem to get the multicast setup correctly with VMWare, thus I can't control the simulation from the host.  

However, I can control the limb without any trouble locally (to the guest).  

Do you guys have experience with this kind of setup, using a VM as opposed to a multicast network appliance.

I would be happy to install Gazebo on my host PC but I was concerned that the haptix communication was dependent on this particular version of Gazebo.

Thanks,

Elliott
content.html:
Hi,

I'm a HAPTIX collaborator using the HAPTIX-Gazebo simulation to do some EMG modelling. I would like to run Gazebo in a VM, (I'm currently using VMWare workstation 12) and develop the code that will be controlling the simulation on my host PC, a Linux PC (Ubuntu 17.04).

I followed the instructions to install and run Gazebo from here: http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?cat=haptix&tut=haptix_install As such, I used Ubuntu 14.04. This is running on the Guest.

I can't seem to get the multicast setup correctly with VMWare, thus I can't control the simulation from the host.

However, I can control the limb without any trouble locally (to the guest).

Do you guys have experience with this kind of setup, using a VM as opposed to a multicast network appliance.

I would be happy to install Gazebo on my host PC but I was concerned that the haptix communication was dependent on this particular version of Gazebo.

Thanks,

Elliott
